Review Text: Do you know how this name came. Arasi means rice in Tamil. This beach sand is like rice. Like samba rice. and i heard that this is the only beach where you can find this kind of sand drops. go and see for your self. Nice experience. there were many small ports in this beach are which belongs to various provincial kings who ruled this area
This is one of a unique place where you can find in Trincomalee. Sand of the beach is really different from the other beaches. My view is that it’s better to visit the beach in the evening.

It is believed that two merchants, Thapassu and Bhalluka, who received locks of hair of the lord Buddha have landed here. From here they have travelled up to Thiriyaya to deposit it in Girihanduseya stupa. There are a large number of archaeological artefacts in this region. Now a great stupa cold Thpasu Bhalluka Mahaseya is under construction here. There is also a very good Buddhist meditation centre called Arisimale Aranya Senasanaya nearby (Trip 0718562700).

Review Title: Nowhere found sand like the size of Rice got in a small beach near Pulmudai.
Review Text: The sand found here is unique as it's size is as the grain of Rice. In Tamil Arisi means rice Male means the beach.The sand got on your feet can be wiped off easily as they do not stick on the legs like other sand. It is a small beach.It is in Pulmudai which is 60 km away from Trincomalee along Nilaweli Uppuweli road. You have to travel in a semi forest area to get there.Do not take the road leading to the Arisimalee Temple as it is not at the beach. You can walk in the lagoon to get here also as the water is not deep. Paul.udai has black beaches generally rich in Ilmanite. This place is a lovely one for a swim and it is calm and quiet.The water is crystle clear and not deep. Little waves are experienced. The view is also superb. There is a Navy camp nearby and you have to park your vehicles before it and walk about 1/ 2 km to come to the beach.
This is a good beach just out of Trincomalee. There is a Navy camp so there is security. You can not take your vehicle close ,you have to walk a bit to the beach.

It's a rare beach you can find because of it's location and the sand. Beach sand almost similar to rice thereby it's called as "Arisimalai" in the local language. The crystal clear water and the slight waves will make you curious if you bath there. Highly recommend to visit if you cross Pulmodai, Sri Lanka eventhough it's quiet difficult to be there.

Review Title: Hidden beach with rice like sand and awesome views around
Review Text: An unique beach with wet rice like sand which also gives the name for this place. View is superb all around. Good to visit early morning for sunrise. When you are coming from nilaveli side take the route shown by google maps if you are traveling in a low ground clearance vehicle. If not there’s a short cut as well which is also shown in the map yet not recommended. There you have a board mentioning the road to arisimale temple. We took this road and hardly managed to reach the beach with a lot of effort in maneuvering the vehicle. But all that effort was worthwhile after seeing the view from the beach. There’s a navy camp there and you need to park the vehicle outside and walk about 500m through the jungle. Good to visit if you are in Trincomalee.
amazing experience, In srilanka we cant find any beach like this it consist with little bit large sand grains which not highly watered from transportation.

Arisimale beach is a small beautiful beach, This beach is located in Pulmudai at Trincomalee. The Arisimale Beach is famous because of extremely large particles of sand, the size and shape of a rice seed.

Located apprx 60km from trinco town. Welknown for the sand which like rice. Unfortunately we couldnt see that sand and no idea whether we visited in wrong period. However lovely beach you can see a black beach too..stunning views and itz like another gungle beach !!

A unique place. In my first visit, the location was superb. But now people have spoiled the area with garbage. Still the physical formation of rocky beach is wonderful. Best at sun set. Sea bathing may be dangerous since no safe guard is located nearby.
In Trincomalee it is beach beach every where. But still I feel the beauty nature has bestowed on each is different and each surpasses the other.

I accidentally discovered Arisimale Beach while i was in Pulmudaai area.  while speaking to a resident of Pulmudaai in the beach, he suggested that we visit Arisimale beach which was about 1 KM away from where i was. with his guidance manged to get there on foot in 20 minutes. It was amazing to note the pebble like sand in this beach when compared to blackish sand in Pulmudaai beach. I found quite a few western tourist enjoying themselves on the beach.
good beach like rice sand hide place in tricomalee 50 km ahead close to pulmudai. deep sea careful swimming

Nice beach. Calm and scenic. The specialty of this is it has an unique sand type. The name it self says that in Tamil (Arisi = Rice). You have to go through a forestry path way for about 250m. But, the scene is fantastic. Most people mislead with the beach very near (beyond few rocks), but the actual beach is far.

Accidentally discovered Arisimale beach thanks to a villager while wondering in Pulmuddai beach 2 weeks ago. It was just 10 minutes walk across the lagoon (water Knee high) from where i was. It's nice secluded path leading to the beach. I was surprised to see few foreign nationals were already having a swim in the calm sea with crystal clear water. The sand there is quite unique and grainy like rice. Very easy to brush off as it does not stick to your feet. I regret not going prepared to have a swim. Highly recommended for a swim. Please do not litter in and around this pristine clear beach
We went there in April. It's a very nice place with scenic beauty. We took a lot of photos. Soil looks like rice. So it has it's name .

In all of sri lanka this is the first time I have seen a sand which  is the size of “samba rice”, an unique beach when compared other beached around sri lanka  , finding the pace was an bit of a challenge cause there was no directions given to the place , there is an navy check point  as you enter the beach area ,where they tell you if It’s safe to bath in the sea or not. I think is an must see place to get an idea on what is written

Although I was travelling with Sri Lankan friends it took us quite a while to find this place. To get to it we parked the car, waded across a river estuary, went through a military check point and then followed the steep and winding path to the beach (in a natural bay). And it is true the location is idyllic and the sand very unusual as it really does look and feel like grains of rice My only disappointment was to see the huge amount of rubbish., plastic bottles, flip flops and many other unsavoury items that had been washed up here - tragic It is not possible to explore the area too much as part of it is a military zone and another area occupied by a Buddhist monastery which is off limits to visitors

This is one of the wonderful location that i have ever visited in Sri Lanka. Sand is like rice. access to this place is bit difficult by a car. But definitely a one of the place they you tryout in Pulmudai road, Trincomalee.

A beach with sand looks like Rice. In Tamil “Asiri” means Rice. The meaning of the name is Heap of Rice. Please avoid the rough sea season Feb – Mar, then you can have a see bath there. However, want to be more careful because there is a Buddhist Temple where monks are meditating.

Something unique to this place is it's sand, which looks exactly like uncooked grains of sand! The access path to this location lays through a patch of low and high shade trees. Watch closely by the military; this place is well maintained. A must visit!

The beach side sand is exactly like wet uncooked small rice like keeri samba. It's nice to walk on the beach. However, with hot climate the walking way to the beach is bit difficult. Must walk through forest and rocks for like 10 minutes after parking the vehicles.
No sand, sand like rice !! We went with five buddies. Have to obey to rules. There is a temple. Good for fun.

Arisi means Rice in Tamil language Malai means Mountain ARISI MALAI means rice mountain This is a hidden beach you have find your way locals will guide you. This is also under the Navy protection.  you may find navy personnel patrolling this area. Beach is very beautiful and very clean and crystal clear water comparing with other beaches in this area (Nilavei, Uppuveli etc.) this is not very wide but you fine peace and calm in this area. Sometimes you feel bit scared also but mostly it is safe. There is no entry fees

Its a bit hard to find as one has to cross a stream and walk through a thicket. Once you get the beach in sight its breathtaking view make you feel 'its really worth the effort' However the icing is in the bathing experience. The sand here is not the fine grain sand its the size of rice grains and I was told 'Arisi means Rice grains in Tamil and hence the Name Arisimale.

We found it hard to find even with GPS on the mobile phone and asking people on the way. Finally, we found it and walked about 300m through a shrub jungle to get to the lovely little beach. There were very few people here. The Navy personnel in charge instructed us not to be noisy nor go over the rocky crags as there is a hermitage in the vicinity. What is special about this beach is that the sand resembles a particular rice grain.
